channel.title: Advent of Code 2024 on jverkamp.com
channel.description: Recent content in Advent of Code 2024 on jverkamp.com

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 14: Chaosinator
item.description:
Source: Day 14: Restroom Redoubt

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 14: Restroom Redoubt
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
    • Optimization 1: Weird shape detection
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

Given a series of robots defined with initial position and velocity on a 101x103 toroidal grid, calculate where the robots will be after 100 iterations. Return the product of the number of robots in each quadrant of the final grid, ignoring the middle lines (since they’re odd).

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 13: Cramerinator
item.description:
Source: Day 13: Claw Contraption

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 13: Claw Contraption
  • Part 1
    • Optimization 1: Cramer’s Rule
  • Part 2
  • Benchmarks
  • Optimization 2: Really going off the deep end

Part 1

Given Button A (ax, ay), Button B (bx, by), and Prize (px, py); how many times must you press Button A (a) and Button B (b) to reach the Prize? Sum 3a + b for each machine that has a solution.

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 12: Edginator
item.description:
Source: Day 12: Garden Groups

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 12: Garden Groups
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
    • Optimization 1: Detect corners instead of edges
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

Given a Grid of regions, calculate the sum of the product perimeter * area for each region.

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 11: Exponential Growthinator
item.description:
Source: Day 11: Plutonian Pebbles

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 11: Plutonian Pebbles
  • Part 1
    • Optimization 1: Recursion
    • Optimization 2: Memoization
  • Part 2
    • Optimization (attempt) 3: Association list cache
    • Optimization (attempt) 4: BTree cache
    • Optimization 5: Iterate over HashMap<value, count>
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

Given a sequence of values v_n, replace each value with the first matching rule:

  • if v = 0 -> 1
  • If v has an even number of digits, split it (so v = 8675 becomes [86, 75])
  • Otherwise, v -> v * 2024

Calculate how many elements are in the sequence after 25 iterations.

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 10: Take-a-Hikinator
item.description:
Source: Day 10: Hoof It

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 10: Hoof It
  • Part 1
    • Optimization 1: Using dynamic programming
    • Optimization 2: Smarter bitmasks
  • Part 2
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

Given a heightmap (0 to 9), for each 0 count how many 9 you can reach on paths that only ever increase height by exactly 1 at a time. Sum these values.

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 9: Defraginator
item.description:
Source: Day 9: Disk Fragmenter

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 9: Disk Fragmenter
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
    • Optimization (attempt) 1: BTree representation
  • Optimization 2: Track the leftmost empty space
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

Given a disk layout alternating between files and empty spaces, move all files as early on the disk is possible, splitting into multiple blocks. Return a checksum on the disk.

Alternating means: 23331 would mean a 2 block file, 3 empty, a 3 block file, 3 empty, and a 1 block file.

The checksum is the sum of file_id * block_index for all occupied blocks. File IDs are assigned sequentially on initial generation.

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 8: Vectorinator
item.description:
Source: Day 8: Resonant Collinearity

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 8: Resonant Collinearity
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

Given a grid with either open tiles (.) or towers (anything else), for each pair of towers, there is an antinode at each of the points that is 2x as far from one tower as the other. How many antinodes are there still within the bounds of the map?

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 7: Mathinator
item.description:
Source: Day 7: Bridge Repair

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 7: Bridge Repair
  • Part 1
    • Optimization (attempt) 1: Queue
  • Part 2
  • A ‘cleaner’ way of looking at it: OpSet
  • Benchmarks
  • Future work

Part 1

Given a result and a list of numbers, determine if any combination of addition (+) and/or multiplication (*) using all the given numbers in order can return the result. Ignore order of operations.

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 6: Wanderinator
item.description:
Source: Day 6: Guard Gallivant

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 6: Guard Gallivant
  • Part 1
    • Direction
    • Point
    • Actually solving the problem
  • Part 2
    • Optimization 1: Only checking the path
    • Optimization 2: Rayon parallelization
    • Optimization 3: Avoiding clone
    • Optimization 4: No hash
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

You are given a grid of walls (#), floors (.), and a guard (^, initially facing up/north). The guard walks forward until they run into a wall at which point they turn right. How many tiles does the guard reach before leaving the map.

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 5: (Not) Transitivinator
item.description:
Source: Day Day 5: Print Queue

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day Day 5: Print Queue
  • Part 1
    • Parsing
    • Is it transitive?
  • Part 2
  • Benchmarks
  • Optimization 1: Drop the hashmap
  • Optimization 2: bitvec
  • Optimization (attempt) 3: A vec of pairs
    • Optimization (attempt) 4: Sorted vec of pairs
  • Overall timing graph

Part 1

The input is a list of pairs of the form a|b which defines that b must not come before a, an empty line, and then a list of values a,b,c,d.

For each line that is valid for all given a|b rules, sum the middle number of each list.

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 4: Gridnator
item.description:
Source: Day 4: Ceres Search

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 4: Ceres Search
  • Part 1
    • Grid
    • Iterating over XMAS
    • Optimization 1: Less loops
  • Part 2
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

Given a grid of letters, count how many times XMAS appears in any direction (horizontally, vertically, diagonally; forward or backward).

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 3: Mulinator
item.description:
Source: Day 3: Mull It Over

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 3: Mull It Over
  • Part 1
    • Optimization 1: Use nom
    • Optimization 2: Manual parsing / state machine
  • Part 2
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

Given a string containing (among other gibberish) commands of the form mul({A}, {B}) where {A} and {B} are integers, calculate the sum of A*Bs.

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 2: Safinator
item.description:
Source: Day 2: Red-Nosed Reports

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 2: Red-Nosed Reports
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
  • Optimization 1: Don’t clone vec
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

Count how many given lists of numbers are safe:

  1. Sorted (either ascending or descending)
  2. Strictly increasing/decreasing (no duplicate values)
  3. No increase/decrease is by more than 3

item.title: AoC 2024 Day 1: Sortinator
item.description:
Source: Day 1: Historian Hysteria

Full solution for today (spoilers!).

  • Source: Day 1: Historian Hysteria
  • Part 1
  • Part 2
  • Benchmarks

Part 1

Given two lists of numbers arranged in columns in a file, find the sum of differences (in sorted order).

item.title: Advent of Code 2024
item.description:
Let’s do this (Advent of Code) thing again!

I’m sticking with Rust again. I still use Python when I need to hammer out something quickly, but if I want to do something correctly (and especially if I want it to be fast), you can’t beat Rust.

Let’s see how it goes!

Full solutions will once again be posted to GitHub (including previous years and possibly some I haven’t written up yet): jpverkamp/advent-of-code
